review_title: Like drinking from a firehose all the time - but in a good way
pros: These folks took a chance on me a few years ago, and I learned so much from so many. It was always my absolute pleasure to log in every morning and do my job for our contact center agents. If you get a chance, get yourself a job at one of these nonprofits because, from day one, you will learn on the job like you wouldn't believe. If you have a loved one with a recent diagnosis, encourage them to reach out (toll-free) and speak to one of our agents (day or night). Tell them, "The old WFM guy said it was important to call right away." - the pros will take it from there.
cons: It was always a possibility, and you prepare for it as well as you can, but it'll hurt a little if you get let go (for budget reasons)

review_title: Chews passionate people up and spits them back out
pros: - Great benefits and solid pay. - The mission is genuinely incredible - You can learn a lot about a pervasive issue that most people know nothing about. - The people attracted to work here are passionate, intelligent, creative and knowledgeable. - If you go out of your way to do so, you can really impact individual lives in a big way. I've had some experiences that I wouldn't trade for the world that I never would have had outside of this job.
cons: If you look at the other reviews, you'll see a disparity between development roles (mostly negative) and the other departments. As the association has an overall 4-star score, it's safe to assume that the score for development roles would likely be 1 star. I have friends at chapters all over the country, and we all face the same struggles. The following issues are nation-wide. We all wish we'd known one thing before accepting the position: regardless of what your interviewer might tell you, you're being hired to do one thing - to meet a financial goal. You will be evaluated entirely on your capacity to do so. As you attempt to meet your goal, you will be inundated with data entry, web/graphic design, tech issues, corporate bureaucracy/politics, bloated meetings, useless trainings and countless irrelevant emails. These responsibilities are enough for a separate full time job. Since being hired, my chapter has lost half of its senior staff, and the rest are "actively looking". Those facts alone should be enough to make you stop and think. But in case they're not, here are some more. - My coworkers routinely cry during 1 on 1 meetings with me. We all joke about having daily panic attacks, but we're not actually joking. - Pressure from the out-of-touch upper management leads to pressure on front-line employees. This leads to clique culture, finger pointing, and chronic gossiping/trash-talk. I cannot stress enough how mentally taxing it is to know that your coworkers are all talking trash about each other. - The obscene work load makes it impossible for managers to properly train new hires. We were all thrown to the wolves with nothing but a few online learning modules to lean on. No new leads. No returning fundraisers. Just a pat on the back, and a "go get em', tiger".

pros: Your coworkers that is the only reason. The people on the same level as you are the only pro.
cons: Let’s see, micromanaging, only caring about money being brought in not the actual mission of the organization and people in executive positions care nothing about you. The executives only want to make theirselves look good and do not care the stress nor how they treat people that they supervise. It is a favoritism organization. I personally had 4 immediate supervisors while I was there for over a year. There is a very high turnover rate, that alone should be a red flag for anyone wanting to work for this non-profit. I would NEVER work there again. Horrible organization!

pros: Immediate supervisor and state lead were great leaders because they cared about their employees.

review_title: Great Place to Work…with Important Caveats
pros: Kind, caring colleagues. Manageable scope of work. Association is attentive to employees as human beings and has policies, benefits, and norms that support people’s lives outside the office. Health insurance is comprehensive and generous, and retirement contributions are the best I’ve seen in nonprofit. It’s overall a wonderful working environment.
cons: Legacy thinking. Legacy systems. Belief that the organization is a “well oiled machine” when it is anything but. Brand is stale and lacks inspiration and strategic continuity. Continued focus on scaling through grass roots engagement versus digital transformation. Lack of decision-making agility among leadership. Desire for strategic progress despite a cultural inability to embrace new ways of thinking and working. This results in a “growth = more of the same” mindset that has the organization falling behind.

review_title: Burn out. Greed. Cog in a machine.
pros:
- Blue Cross Blue Shield of IL benefits 
- 3-4 weeks off plus holidays 
- Potential for hybrid work 
- Learning opportunities
- Overall LGBTQ+ friendly (depends on the manager, too)
cons:
- The Association as a whole is greedy when it comes to getting donations from their constituents. "That's ALL they gave??" (quote from NY manager)
- HR is not great. They discourage sharing salary/earnings so they can continue to underpay their hardest workers (NY). When I came on, I was told not to share my salary with my coworkers because "people who had worked there for years made less" than I did, even though I was just their assistant.
- To get their employees to fundraise more money for their Walk to End Alzheimer's, they push (they say they don't, but it's a ton of pressure) each employee to sign up, make a team, and raise or PAY money into that team. The goals for each chapter are ridiculous, and if you earn more money one year as a chapter, you better be ready to fundraise even MORE the next year 
- Raises were 3-5% at best in 2021. They lauded themselves as good employers for not even giving their best employees enough of a raise to cover inflation.
- You may be able to take the vacation you earned. But you'll also come back to heaps of work, and they'll call/email you on vacation, too (NY).
- Everyone gets drunk at their annual conference.
- Shockingly, there's high turnover. 5+ people quit in 12 months. (20-person team)

Overworked and understaffed in some areas. Plan to work through lunch, bring work home, and work weekends. Does not value hard work or results. No meeting agendas or action items. Everything is ad hoc and poorly scheduled. Siloed work. Salary is below market.

pros: Great CEO. Great Mission. Great benefits.
cons: Everything was fantastic until the pandemic hit, then everything changed. What really hurt was the work/life balance shift. I was expected to work late nights and early mornings, and I was repeatedly told it was part of the job when attempting to set boundaries. Expected to reach lofty goals that were raised two fold during the pandemic. Low low low salary for what you are asked to do for the organization. Hit goals over and over for a 2 percent annual raise, no where near on pace with inflation. Worked 60 plus hours a week for 5 years when “37.5 hours” are what’s in the contract.   Even when you hit yours goals, it’s never enough, and you will absolutely burn out with time.  I would not recommend working here because the mission becomes lost in the  politics and you will be underpaid and will burnout.

pros: My co-workers were amazing people.
cons:
Being tethered to your desk answering calls all day is hard. It just is. But, in addition to that, the computer also monitors all your time, even bathroom breaks. Have you ever gotten to work, put a couple of hours in and then gotten up to go to the bathroom and while on the way, had a rude comment made by the big boss because you’re going to the bathroom? I have. That happened to me MANY times working in the Contact Center. I worked hard and provided quality service to the callers. I should have been able to use the bathroom without having a comments made to me, as if I was slacking. Truly bizarre and abusive. I’ve never experienced anything like it and I’ve had some strange jobs. There are many other examples of like behavior, but I honestly think the bathroom thing best exemplifies the dysfunction.
Then, they talk about making time for self-care, but it’s all just lip service and so they can say they encourage self-care. There’s a lot of attention paid to optics rather than reality. Extra tasks are treated like rewards. It’s super hard to get time off approved, even if you ask well in advance. They play favorites. Some managers are good (a couple, including my direct supervisor, I loved) and some are so awful. I loved loved loved my co-workers, though. Great people. They were my people but it was not my place.

cons: There is no work/life balance, be expected to work after hours and weekends unless you have an excuse. No way to move up from lower level positions. Racism, homophobia, and xenophobia engrained. Wage gaps between gender and race are prevalent. The pay is low. BIPOC opportunities are limited. Even if it's not in your job description and you have no knowledge of it before you were hired, you will be expected to do it within a moment's notice and not even be thanked. You will pick up the work of others that will scathe by unnoticed by management. And the ultimate con, they view everyone including volunteers as expendable.

pros: Generous PTO, flexibility SOMETIMES, coworkers and volunteers who genuinely care about the mission
cons:
This is one of the worst places I’ve ever worked in my life. It’s sad because it has potential to be a wonderfully rewarding job but management style and structures laid out by the National office create discouragement and employee burnout. I would literally have panic attacks at least once a week.

The priorities of the organization became very clear to me once the pandemic happened. Most of our support programs were cut but demands continued to grow. Rather than creating an understanding and empathetic environment for employees and volunteers during such a difficult time, pressure, micromanagement and lofty goals increased tenfold. Decrease in fundraising led to my boss suggesting I encourage volunteers to hold in-person fundraising events despite cdc recommendations and covid restrictions. Since I wasn’t comfortable doing that, I was punished with over the top surveillance and unrealistic tasks expected to be completed within unmanageable time frames. My revenue goals were doubled despite the ongoing pandemic and financial distress my communities were in. I anticipated a bigger push due to a decrease in fundraising but the way in which the association (my chapter in particular) went about this push was distasteful, greedy, disrespectful and shameful. It has not only affected me as an employee but has also discouraged my volunteers who are the backbone of the organization.

Before covid, my direct supervisor gave me little to no mentorship or real guidance, encouraged me to lie to volunteers on multiple occasions, cut corners to reach unrealistic metrics goals, and ignored employee concerns. The mission of the organization was completely lost and I strongly question where all the money raised is actually going. This is not a non-profit organization, it’s a corporation.

job_title: Chief Executive Officer in Southwest, PA
pros: Staff is committed to their work and interacts with family members well and with respect.  The 24-hour helpline is probably their best outreach into the Alzheimer's community.
cons:
Pathetic boards as a rule.  Very immature and focused more on bringing accolades to themselves than on research, treatment, and energizing new researchers.  Boards do not truly grasp the roles of advocacy and fundraising; they focus more on hearing and voting on reports, tweaking investments, and in some cases, micromanaging staff!  When these actions are brought up, watch out - don't show them examples of high performing boards from Board Source, for example.  Members focus on tactics, not strategy.  

The present configuration of independent chapters and an overarching national org frequently causes trouble identifying the strategies for all in governance to follow.  Allowing persons to serve on local and national boards may seem like a feather in the chapter's cap, but in reality can cause conflict where the local board wants to go with one direction vs. the national direction.

review_title: Great Mission, Great People, Integrity Check Needed

The Senior staff are great, they get to know you but unfortunately they don't have a lot of control on the HR side of things so often, they are left out of the loop.
cons: Unfortunately, the caregiving angle stops at other diseases outside Alzheimer's.  Be careful at what is promised and always be sure to watch your back.  Your general colleagues outside of management (Directors and above) are a great, fun team to work with.  Unfortunately the seniored directors have all been there together and watch out for each other.

review_title: My experience at the Alzheimer's Association was incredibly positive.
job_title: Chief Executive Officer in Orange, CA
pros: The Association is a great place to work because it is a national voluntary health agency with a variety of opportunities as well as the opportunity to advance within a chapter or across the nation.  The mission is so important at this time because Alzheimer's is becoming an epidemic.  It is an easy mission to get behind and fully support.  Colleagues at the national level and throughout chapters across the nation are supportive and easy to work with.  I would highly recommend the Alzheimer's Association to anyone interested in a career in not-for-profit whether it be in development, programs, communication or finance.
cons: No cons as long as you are meant for the not-for-profit arena.

review_title: Great people, LOW pay and no room for advancement
pros:
Great people! I can honestly say I work with people who are normal, hard working and easy to be around. 
I can take time off without my boss getting mad about it. Lots of flexibility and comp time. The work-life balance is wonderful!
cons: LOW PAY! I mean it's non profit so of course I know I'm not going to be a millionaire but it certainly gets frustrating not being able to save and hav extr income. Also, we have a huge territory and I have put 60,000 miles on my car in 2 years which is frustrating considering I make a terrible income.

review_title: Constant turnover, Money over Mission, Poor local leadership
pros: Co-worker workers and families/caregivers/colleagues are wonderful. Work is rewarding and meaningful.
cons: Lots of performative "staff appreciation", but if you're not bringing in money through fundraising, your work is marginalized and devalue. They talk about The Mission, but at the top, it's about money, and not because money funds the Mission, but because chapter executives are in a constant rat race for recognition by National leadership in hopes of climbing that ladder. Internally, there's little room for advancement for staff: you stay where you started. In the chapter I worked at, everyone cowered at the intimidating and mercurial whims of our executive, which caused staff to bail regularly and left us in chaos. There was no accountability for poor leadership as long as the fundraising was satisfactory.

pros: The overall idea and goal of kind of helping families dealing with Alzheimer's is a good thing. They offer benefits, but most companies do this. Employees still have to pay for it. Great benefits offered would mean that the employee has no money taken out of their already very small paycheck, to pay for the monthly premium.
cons:
All they are focused on is raising money. Being a non-profit, you would think they would treat their employees better, but that is not the case. When, on average, HALF the staff quits every year and a half, you need to look at the common denominator. When staff gets paid very little and also gets treated poorly, they will not stick around. 

If an employee has a position that, the government says, should be getting overtime then the employee that is forced to work overtime (time and a half) should be getting paid for overtime. Not paying overtime is considered illegal!

review_title: Overpaid Senior Team, CEO Needs to Go
pros: This is a review for the Greater Illinois Chapter. Pros are definitely the mission and overall most of the staff actually care about the mission. Also, pretty good work/life balance and PTO.
cons: Erna Colborn makes nearly $300,000 a year and "works" from her hometown in Rockford part of the week. The rest of the senior team makes nearly $500,000! Everyone else is underpaid and told that the will get more money "soon" but never happens. The CEO and Chief Development Officer have dozens and dozens of complaints from donors and past staff but the Board does nothing. The moral is so low after more than 8 people " have left" since a year ago. Lisa Lee is toxic -- stay away from this place!

review_title: Gratifying work. Fast paced. Wonderful mission.
pros: Development department offers the possibility for learning many areas of work and skills. You must have a willingness to wear many hats and be quick on your feet. There is room for growth - you have to be willing to put in the time. The cause is necessary and the national strategy is clear.
cons: Strategic decisions are made at the national level with relative disregard for what might be right for a specific region. You must drink the cool-aide or you may as well look for new employment.

review_title: I've never been more fulfilled with a job
pros: After working my entire career in for-profit, I thought I would lose pay or benefits by entering the nonprofit world...not so.  The Alzheimer's Association, Illinois Chapter as well as the national organization cares about employees and attracting and maintaining the best and the brightest.  Best environment I've ever worked in.
cons: There is so much need, it can be frustrating when you can only do so much.  However, great strides are made every day and I am confident that we will see a major breakthrough in the near future.

review_title: Great mission and staff but limited career development
pros: Exceptional staff, great benefits, amazing cause to be supporting.
cons:
A senior management team led by a few high ranking decisions makers.

A  management team, that does not mentor, welcome or adapt to junior staff with new ideas. Sometimes it feels as if new ideas are not welcomed. There seems to be a desire to maintain the way things are done, rather than grow. This seems to be the case in the departments of Marketing, Business Development and Ecommerce.

Advancement can be tricky and sometimes employees careers or job titles being re-classified as non-promotable, after several years on tenure.

job_title: Education Specialist/Program Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Great way to network and learn about various community resources that are available. Great benefits for single individuals, families/couples not so great benefits.
cons: No real growth opportunities. Pay for an MSW was under $30k. Rewarding to work with caregivers and provide information to the community. Micromanagement and employee favoritism evident. Expect to work 40+ hours a week, time-off policies aren't great. Wouldn't reconsider going back to organization for a career. Expect to you stay in office for majority of the time, yet they also expect you to provide numerous programs in the community...conflict.

review_title: Best job and boss I have ever had
pros: The job I was hired to do was office manager of the Greater Illinois Chapter in Rockford and my boss helped me grow as I took on more responsibilities. She was instrumental in my rise to become her assistant as she became President & CEO of the Chapter. I have never respected anyone more than her.
cons: I only wish I had paid more attention to the disease because now my husband has been diagnosed with Early Stage Alzheimer's and I am feeling helpless.  I'm so glad the Chapter has such strong leadership and staff to help me through this.

pros: I love the chance to help people who are going through something terrible. I work with amazing people who care about the mission and the people we serve.
cons: The calls can be really stressful. Sometimes we talk to people who are at the end of their rope and there may be no easy answers or quick fixes. Sometimes it gets really busy. We are 24/7. That means some of us work weekends, late evenings, and overnight. While the rest of the office goes home early before a holiday, we say here and work till the end of our shift. We all work some holidays.

pros:
The Alzheimer’s Association is a top notch nonprofit. While others in the sector are seeing declining revenue, this organization continues to make great gains.

Harry Johns is an outstanding CEO with a strong vision.  Efforts are being made to ensure the organization functions as one which will improve operations. 

This organization promotes internally, appreciates longevity and treats employees with dignity and respect. 

If you’re looking to work in the nonprofit sector this is a winning place to work!
cons: Salaries are not competitive with other national voluntary organizations. However, benefits are solid.

review_title: Great Nat'l Company; beware inexperienced local mgmt.
pros: It is a great organization, does important work for families that really need assistance.  The organization has a good supportive board that really cares about the cause, and is supportive of the staff, and gets involved in both day to day activities and fundraisers and special events.
cons: Occasionally a board member will be incompetent or know far more less than they think; or a manager will be inexperienced and drive employees away.  Hopefully their past issues will not hold them back, because overall the organization is important to the community.

review_title: A humorless environment but the employees mean well.
pros: The Alzheimer's Association does really great work in the community and everyone employed at the Regional Offices really seem to have incredible knowledge and dedication.
cons: The office is grey and white and small. Dealing with Alzheimer's disease is fairly depressing work and the fact that it is so highly frowned upon to be able to have any sort of cheer in the office or laugh with your co-workers for a few moments to blow off much-needed steam is really unfortunate and it makes this a pretty dismal palce to have to go each day.

review_title: Illinois Chapter great place to grow, risk tolerant
pros: Very supportive of staff with ideas - though not everyone steps up with ideas.  When I presented my idea to senior management, they jumped on the idea and let me run with it. It went very well and I got a $ bonus for my success.  Not all employers willing to do that.  Good medical and dental benefits, 401K match, good PTO, life and disability insurance.
cons: There are always whiners in every org - this one is no different.  But if you can ignore them, you can excel.

pros: if you want to get your feet wet in the world of development this is a great place to learn the trade. You will get more than enough chances to pitch to anyone who has given in the past; we have a great data base.
cons: If you really truly want to help out famlies you will quickly learn this is not the place for you.  It seems the number one goal is to raise money and if somewhere along the way we give some good advise it was pure luck.

pros:
- Very supportive environment
- Showed appreciation for my work
- Felt like part of a team with a positive mission
- Really nice colleagues and atmosphere
- Important work in the fight against Alzheimer's disease
cons: Really wanted to stay and grow my career here, and presented my boss with a plan. Unfortunately, there was not the budget or an opportunity to turn my part time job into full time. Could not stay because I needed a full time job with higher pay.

review_title: "Noble" Intentions, Poor Reality, and a Toxic Structure
pros:
-Several parts of the organization truly do help people and family facing this awful disease. Early Stage efforts provide a tangible way in which people with Alz can have a great environment.
-Referral service is good for families.
-Depending on where you are in the org, you will likely feel good about helping people.
cons:
-This non-profit is pretty limited in providing help. Unless you want a list of nursing homes, an educational program, brochures, professional training, or day program, they really cannot help you. Alzheimer' Association is not too hands-on when compared to elder care companies.
-There is beoming a greater emphasis on fundraising at the expense of programs and services for people dealing with Alzheimer's. Money is the end-all-be-all for this non-profit, and I believe they will continue on this trajectory. The national chapter dictates much of the vision and is implemented on a chapter level. Harry Johns is leading the way into becoming more digitally-grounded (which may sound good at first, but it is at the expense of providing local, personable care). Several job descriptions are slowly changing to becoming more development-oriented (i.e. community partnerships = potential $$$$$).
-With such small chapters, chances are you will have no room for growth or professional development.
-At my particular branch, senior leadership micromanaged employees and squashed innovation and creativity. Manager-level staff continually would have to fight uphill battles. There is a significant division among staff. Most trust managers but do not trust local CEO/national.
-Unnecessary drama between board/senior leadership/other staff. Some employees were very rude and unprofessional to colleagues.
-Pay was significantly subpar considering other NGOs in the area (Even for people with masters degrees). The structure promotes a tight cash flow and prizes saving money over compensating employees.
-Raises and bonuses are hard to come by. Unless you work in development/fundraising, then for some reason you get a bonus each year.
-Quality of "benefits" was less than average.
-Salaried employees are treated as hourly workers. Leadership prized office-time over results.
-Staff retention is alarmingly low. In the time I was there, it was at around 50% per year. Instead of examining staff-satisfaction, senior leadership assumed it was a "personnel problem" instead of a sign of a decaying structure.
-They have unrealistic hiring expectations and process. Not uncommon to be interviewed 5+ times with no definitive clarity until job offer. They also prefer several years experience for some of the most basic or entry level jobs. Forget everything you learned in salary negotiation- don't even try to negotiate on compensation- it' hopeless (there's supposedly "no flexibility at this time").

pros: The people that I have the pleasure of working with are the reason I love what I do, and I am very passionate about the mission. Everyone is extremely dedicated to the cause and works overtime for the benefit of the organization. Every day is meaningful and you are often inspired by the people you cross paths with.
cons: Low pay and lack of work/life balance, lack of appreciation shown to employees who work excessive hours

review_title: Love some things about this org, others not so much
pros: They have vision, a stellar cause and stay focused on what needs to be done to eradicate Alzheimer's. They employ some extraordinary people, some of the best in the non-profit world. The pay is quite decent for a non-profit, nearly commensurate with industry. They provide all the tools a person needs, and all sorts of great benefits.
cons:
Not sure that upper management in Chicago has a good grasp on what the executive directors are doing at the chapter level, or maybe they know and don't care.  Some EDs are better than others and if you find yourself working for one that is a good schmoozer with the management above them but really isn't a great manager, you're in trouble.  

My manager is so obsessed with rules that sometimes it's hard to get the job done. Decisions this manager makes based on "rules' often makes no sense whatsoever.  Seems like just an exercise in micro-management, as though to prove a point that this manager is the "boss." 

Nepotism. Not sure if it occurs at all chapters, but it sure does at mine. Never seen anything like it. 

This manager also plays favorites . One week an employee is the darling child, the next week that same employee is persona non-grata. That's bad enough but this same executive director pits employees against one another, for what reason I can't imagine. For laughs? Well, it's not funny. It's demoralizing and for an organization that prides itself on fairness, diversity and accomplishment it's quite the oxymoron. 

Finally, I've never seen an organization that requires as much training as this one. Yes, all organizations these days require employees to undergo mandatory training, but the level that the Alzheimer's Association requires is out of the ordinary. Sometimes it impacts one's ability to complete a project on time that needs full and undivided attention.

review_title: Great organization to work (and volunteer) for
pros: Top-notch leadership (Erna Colborn, chapter exec and regional lead on the local level, and Harry Johns, CEO on the national level), clear mission and vision, strong strategic plan, terrific support from the home office and the chapter network; strong communication about the organization's direction and any changes, updates, etc.
cons: Still working out our regional/area structure. Not a con, really - just an observation that the organization is going through a period of change. This is for the good of the organization but something to note if you're not a fan of change.

pros:
Flexible hours
Reimbursed for travel
Tons of networking opportunities
Fulfilling job that allowed me to give back to the community
Great office atmosphere 
Employees are passionate about the cause, and it shows!
cons: Although AA reimbursed for travel, the internship itself was 40+ hours a week of unpaid work. I didn't feel like there was a strong onboarding for interns, so I spent the first few weeks somewhat unsure of what to do. There was quite a bit of evening and weekend time required, and weeks could be really long leading up to large events.

pros: Almost everyone working at the company is affected by the disease, and thus they put a lot of passion into their work.  This is also humbling so there aren't many aggressive personalities you find in the organization.
cons:
Short staffed office, sometimes you find yourself doing trivial tasks.
During 2015, the different chapters merged with the national office in Chicago and thus we get a lot of corporate guidelines pushed on us.  As with any large company, contacting higher levels of management can be cumbersome.

job_title: Director of Programs and Services in San Jose, CA
pros: The employees are smart, talented, dedicated and motivated. The families we serve are inspiring. The mission can't be beat. This is a fulfilling place to work.
cons: If you are looking for "just a job" this isn't a good fit. Employees work hard and help one another. Most work extra hours, especially during Walk season.

review_title: Passionate team-players with some organizational issues
pros:
Amazing passion and attitudes in the office
Branch office staff communicates very well
Very generous with working around your schedule in terms of office hours schedules (never any problems if there are doctor's appointments, family conflicts)
Volunteer staff are also passionate, helpful, reliable
cons: Definite organizational issues--items would arrive in my inbox on my days off with the stipulation that I had to turn them around in a couple of hours (very difficult because sometimes I was at my other job or would not have e-mail access).  There are a lot of opportunities for streamlining and budget-trimming, especially regarding the way the central offices communicate with their branch offices.   Central office folks can be a bit entrenched in their "systems" and approaches.  Try making helpful suggestions: your local branch will listen; the central branch may or may not blow you off.  Also, if you are part-time under a certain number of hours per week, they won't offer you any benefits, which is unfortunate, because people working that "part-time" are usually the ones more in-need of such benefits.  (Though I also understand the fiscal reasons for not offering benefits to these people, there are two sides to everything).

pros: The people there were kind and helpful! It was not hard to fit in with the full time workers. I also was able to lend a hand on multiple different projects throughout different which was good for skill set  building! The internship was able to range
cons: I interned during the winter months before Walk season which sometimes were a little slow, but managed to help out with other events which offered good experience.

job_title: President and Chief Executive Officer in Alexandria, VA
pros: Important and compelling cause that needs national and international attention and significantly more  funding to find a cure for Alzheimer's disease.
cons: An organization in cultural and organizational transition with staff and a new board chair and board reflective of both the new and former culture needing to rally under a unified strategy and a new national framework currently being built.

review_title: A truly wonderful place to work.
job_title: Senior Associate Director in Chicago, IL
pros: The senior management seem to really understand the value of retaining people and making the Alzheimer's Association a great place to work.  In addition, there is a definite sense of teamwork and camaraderie amongst the staff.  Consistently voted one of the best non-profits to work for.
cons: Though salaries are competitive, they are a non-profit organization so the salaries tend to be in the moderate range.  They do make up for it in benefits as the 401k match and health insurance are outstanding.

review_title: Great benefits but no room for growth
pros: 5 weeks PTO, shorter Fridays, 10% retirement match, great co-workers, employees who really care about the cause
cons: Professional development and growth not a focus (sometimes it even seems discouraged). Hierarchical culture, with too much focus on individual managers. No flexible work policy or work from home policy in the Chapter. Low salaries, especially for the development staff, even when compared to the nonprofit market rate. Lots of pressure to reach unattainable fundraising and (sometimes) arbitrary organizational goals.

review_title: Great services and support programs, but bad leadership
pros: Programs and services department is a team-oriented environment and get along great with each other and have low turn-over rate. They really care about the people they are serving. Would recommend the programs department to anyone looking for a rewarding career.
cons: Development department is unorganized, mismanaged, last-minute and do not work well together. High turn-over rate, over-worked and isolated from other departments. Not a team environment.Upper management does not work well together, nor communicates thoroughly.

job_title: Community Outreach Coordinator in Ada, OK
pros: Flexible schedule & rewarding work.
cons: The title needs to be Territory Manager or something similar. I covered 17 counties and did way more than coordinate activities. I was the coordinated and executed literally everything for the SE OK office. If you’re in the OKC or Tulsa office you have more support, but satellite offices are the red headed step children. However, they don’t have a rep  full-time in the Ada office any longer because of corporate regulations. No more offices under 50K population.

review_title: Great mission, well-run organization (at headquarters & our chapter), awesome and dedicated coworkers and volunteers.
pros: Stable, well-run nonprofit. Great mission and leadership. Growing field. Our chapter is one of the largest and we have good access to leaders within the organization.
cons: It's difficult to keep growing at the pace of the need in the community, as the number of cases of Alzheimer's continues to increase.

review_title: Not a good place to work
job_title: Public Relations & Social Media Manager in Green Bay, WI
pros: The organization itself has helped make strides in research and also provides educational programs and support groups free of charge
cons: Turn over is excessive. My location has 80% annual turnover which is indicative of the leadership and culture. It’s just not a good work environment which is why people leave when they’ve been there a year. The association itself admits 70% of their 2000+ workforce has been there 4 years or less

pros: Amazing team of people, and supportive staff. Lots of freedom. I have had the opportunity to take ownership of my projects with minimal supervision. It feels good to be trusted and valued.
cons: A bit overworked and underpaid. Communication between people working on different projects can be difficult. Not much of a team atmosphere, such that one person does not have a good idea of what another person does as part of their job function.

review_title: Great organization, but lack of good leadership prevents any foundation of development.
pros: Great organization with lots of programs to help those dealing with Alzheimer's in the community.
cons: Lack of good/consistent leadership, little room for growth. High turnover rate.

review_title: Becoming a cancer society business model, top heavy mngmt
pros: Benefits were decent, some truly caring staff.
cons: Left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing. Compartmentalized, National office makes decisions without knowledge of the chapter regions community, replacing programs with fundraising, politics, making sweeping changes they are neither technologically ready for or staffed for.

pros: The organization has a great mission and great people that work there.  Employees are passionate because many of them have a personal connection to the alzheimer's disease.
cons: There is no work/life balance.  They went through a recent merger and there is little focus on the employees that were already working there.  Employees do not have a voice.

pros:
The Association as a whole has incredible potential for growth. There is an excitement throughout most Chapters and an overall passion for the mission. The work being done is vital. 

Great PTO. Decent salary. Amazing resources available through National.
cons: Chapter specific: Incredibly poor leadership, isolating experience overall, unreasonable fundraising expectations, no support or encouragement, poor team spirit, toxic environment from leadership, major turnover

pros: Friendly and supportive staff, relaxed work environment, excellent benefits and PTO, the work is meaningful and makes an impact, organization is highly regarded in the local community
cons: Not much room for growth in the organization, communication between departments lacks at times, busy times are extremely busy- long hours and weekends are needed often

pros: Great place to learn, take on extraordinary responsibilities, great leadership, great atmosphere, great people, great cause
cons: each branch is it own privately managed 501c3, so in others words it's a small company with not a ton of room for growth if you're looking to "climb the corporate ladder", but hey, it comes with the territory when working for a well managed non-profit that uses its funds wisely.

review_title: Great place to work. Rewarding, fulfilling way to give back and develop professionally within a positive organization.
pros: Very rewarding and allows you to be able to have a sense of fulfillment that is very satisfying professionally and helps you to grow personally as well.
cons: Although it allows for a gratifying career, it may be difficult for some to interact with people afflicted by a disease that hits very close to home for a large portion of people.

pros: Great cause.  Alzheimer's impacts everyone.  Good benefits.  Competitive salary.
cons: Effective 7/1/2016, the 70+ Chapters were merged into one National Organization.  The transition was done too quickly, which has resulted in stress, communication breakdowns, and a significant turnover.  It has also created a multi-layer, top-heavy structure.

pros: As nonprofits go, the benefits at the Alzheimer's Association are better than most.  In particular, they offer a really good retirement (401K) plan.
cons: Autocratic, top-down management.  Stifling, inflexible, entropic bureaucracy.  Independent thinking is actively discouraged.  It's run like a big corporation, not like a nonprofit, and for the most part, that's not a good thing.    The primary focus is on money, not mission; there is far more emphasis on fundraising than on delivery of programs and services.  I left when I realized that this is an organization that I would not care to donate money to.

pros: It's full filling and wonderful work
cons: It will take up every second of you life.   It's a hard job to do with small children or if you want to spend time with your family

pros: Good people, fun environment, semi-flexible schedule if necessary, helping the community.
cons: Every staff member has their own agenda; they're focused entirely on their own activities and unwilling to help with any other activity. Long hours and evening/weekend activities. No one really cares about day to day operations. No structure. No sense of urgency. The people in management are abrasive and insulting. No room for advancement.

review_title: I am dissatisfied with this organizations ability to help me grow as a successful professional in the non-profit field.
pros:
Decent benefits
Mission of organization is worthwhile
They don't over-work you to death
Ability to work independently and not be micro-managed
cons:
Communication lacks within the office environment
Performance reviews not taken seriously
No opportunity for growth
Unorganized business practices
Leadership is lacking for new employees to learn their role

review_title: I worked here as an intern, and it was a mediocre experience.
pros: Everyone was very nice and welcoming, however everyone worked separately for the most part , all in their own offices.
cons: Its frustrating when they give you a list of numbers to call off a spreadsheet and there are numerous errors- repeats, people no longer in those positions, numbers out of service- complete mess.  Also, the day was slow and work assignments were boring.

pros: This was a very rewarding role within the organization, working first hand with constituents who were in need of counseling and local resources. Friendly environment, hard working staff.
cons: There seems to be a bigger emphasis on fundraising than there is on programming. Both teams rely on each other to make the chapter grow, but this should be an equal partnership.

review_title: Excellent outlook, amazing teams, passionate employees
pros: Benefits are excellent, coworkers are intelligent and hardworking, focus is on serving the constituents and people who need help in general.
cons: I am sure some people have their own supervisor or team issues, but I am happy with my team and love working here.

review_title: Unorganized, unwilling to change and in my time there a terrible Board of Directors.
pros: Had a great Executive Director for a short while.
cons: One of my worst experiences in the non-profit industry, the incompetent Board of Directors released a great E.D. and then ravaged the rest of the agency.  They targeted the wrong people and not the ones who were destroying the agency, and stealing from the agency.  The direction was headed downward and the then Board (hopefully it has changed), did not look at potential growth, but remained stagnant and uncompromising.

review_title: Great place to start, not so great for work/life balance
pros: Meaningful work that contributes to a strong need in the community
cons: There is a poor work life balance

review_title: Don't work here - Delaware valley chapter
pros: There some pros. this job did provide job experience and i learned how to network better. however thats where the pros end.
cons:
I am going to list all the cons of this place:

OVERWORKING / SHORT STAFFED
This particular office is always short staffed and will overwork all the staff to make up for the lack of man power due to the employees leaving them constantly. 

PASSING OF RESPONSIBILITIES: 
The fund raising team manager, Keely Boyle, likes to pass her responsibilities to her co-workers (marketing and walk calls)  and  she reaps the benefits from her co-workers work (raises/promotions).     

LACK OF DIVERSITY OUTREACH:

I hear that the diversity team was much larger a few months ago then it is now.  My former co-worker told me that upper management for the diversity department influenced and forced a supervisor to resign. Another person was targeted by the director of diversity  and given too much responsibilities.  in short, most of the resources that are distributed out  are not updated regularly or at all according to some dates that i have seen in my glimpses of handouts while i was there.    


FAVORTISM:

In my time working at this office, i have seen certain people get promotions and other job incentives that did not deserve it.  Management likes to treat the favorites well with promotions and raises yearly. in the even that family members of the employee donates services or money, that person is provided with a certain about immunity from all disciplinary actions.   

GENDER PREFERENCE

This office has a preference for hiring females more then males. it is clearly shown in the ratio of male to female employees.   

GENDER DISCRIMINATION/ DRESS CODE :

The men and woman in this office are told that they have to business casual. Men wear slacks/dress shirt/tie and woman wear dresses/pant suit /etc.  

There is gender discrimination at this work place from my observation. The men are looked at with scrutiny when do not fit the dress code. However female co-worker can wear anything they want. I have seen some female employees come into work with yoga pants on. Not even a word out of management and its usually compliments that the person gets.     

Women also are promoted before men in this office. This is clear in the leadership of this office which all women.

pros: Those that we serve everyday that are not caught up in the politics and strategic goals.  Great mission.  Great volunteers.
cons: High stress level to reach sometime unattainable goals. Top heavy organizational structure. Poor leadership.  Too much focus and recognition given to fundraising and development team while those in client services are ignored.

review_title: Good benefits, no work life balance
pros: benefits, PTO, fantastic peers, great mission
cons: immense pressure to meet numbers, unrealistic expectations, poor work life balance, a lot of time on the road, misunderstanding and miscommunication of expectations, upper management focused on corporate and money and lose sight of the mission, not transparent, lack of additional training, lack of opportunities, unfortunate change in values, poor management of funds.

pros: Opportunities to take on new responsibilities and try new approaches to our work. Supportive staff. Very kind people. Feel like you're making a real impact on families.
cons: No real training programs. Minimal management, which means lots of trial and error and figuring things out on your own. Some staff are much more talented than others.

pros: The Association really concentrates on work life balance. They have good benefits, retirement and PTO plans in place, and the culture is very positive and supportive. They believe strongly in their mission.
cons: Most clients are in the same office as you, which can become difficult to manage. The pay is not as high as you would see outside a nonprofit. Not always a lot of upward movement.

review_title: Wonderful organization that is making a difference in people's lives EVERY day!
pros: Personal fulfillment, professional growth, & excellent benefits.  I was proud to work for such an empowering organization with a great mission.
cons: Nothing to complain about.  Great place to work.

job_title: Public Relations Intern in Fall River, MA
pros: It's a great company to work for, great person to person communication experience and practice. Got to work with some great people and companies involved in the association.
cons: It was tough coordinating my schedule with my supervisor's schedule because he had to take so many out of office meetings so I often had a hard time finding a time that worked for both of us.

pros: Great mission and people - while it is a nonprofit, it is extremely well structured and a professional environment. Working here is a great opportunity to learn from other very talented people.
cons: Pay scale is high for a non profit, but low compared to other industries. A lot will still be expected from employees despite the compensation as is true in many non profits.

pros: Flexibility in both schedule and creating programs, can be easy/light work load, great population.
cons: Short staffing and shifting to a volunteer model, high turnover, poor upper management, no room for growth.

pros: Small but hardworking staff, pursuing an excellent mission. You will feel engaged and active in your work on a daily basis.
cons: Small staff means overstretched staff. Very little group support. Internal office politics can degrade from work quality and decisions to adapt are made slowly if at all. Underpaid, but that is the reality of this line of work.

pros: The Alzheimer's Association is a great non profit to work for. Most of the money raised goes for the purpose it's intended with is helping people cope with Alzheimer's or finding a cure.
cons: A lot is expected from the staff as they are few in numbers. At times it can be stressful. No real cons for working here.

pros: Great mission, a lot of employees "in the trenches" work extremely hard.
cons: Reorganization is completely unorganized.  National is disconnected from chapters which causes chapter leadership to have bad attitudes which rolls down to everyone.

review_title: It has been one of the greatest experiences of my life
pros: It is for a great cause, and the branch I work at is small and intimate. Great way to learn about the nonprofit sector.
cons: It can be depressing work.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Great CAUSE to work for!
Good employee benefits!
Able to work directly with Alzheimer's Patients & their families.
cons:
Poor employee compensation
Too top heavy with administration
Poor funding to complete important duties

job_title: Graphic Design Intern in Chicago, IL
pros:
People really care for each other
Being a non-profit, people come first, not the bottom line
Team atmosphere
As an intern, I was treated with the same respect as everyone else.
cons: I have nothing negative to say about this organization or the work they do.

job_title: Associate Care Manager in Syracuse, NY
pros: The constituents make this job worth while. It is a pleasure meeting so many people in the community who are caregiving for their loved ones and try to help them in their journey.
cons: The supervisors are not supportive, very corporate-like. They are not leaders, and run the non-profit too much like a corporation.

review_title: Great cause but chapter has lost focus of its people.

cons: Low salary, poor manager, micro-manages. Does not trust employees to do their job they have proven to be successful at.

pros: Strong organizational culture and commitment to advancing research. Clear directives related to changing/affecting public policies involving funding for research. Good benefits.

pros: I have worked at other national non profits and I feel we do an excellent job on having local staff in the communities

pros: This is a laid back environment. The people here are friendly.  The hours are very manageable and they don't work you into the ground

review_title: The most painful experience of my entire career!
pros: Great Mission and awesome co-workers
cons:
Work place bullying from boss
No type of mentoring
Clueless Leadership 
No growth opportunity

pros: I enjoy the flexible schedule, people are easy to work with and nice, company is not stressful, and keeps employees information on association business.

pros:

-Phenomenal Volunteers

review_title: Administrative Assistant answer incoming calls,direct calls,file and customer service.
job_title: Reception, Clerical, Administrative Assistant in Las Vegas, NV
pros: I enjoy working for Alzheimer's Association helping others learn about the disease to help that love ones in need.
cons: There's really no cons in this work .,when your helping others to be able to have peace of mind in caring for a love one.

review_title: Great benefits, but no room for personal growth

review_title: Great org with room for improvement
job_title: Development Specialist in San Antonio, TX

cons: Disappointing leadship within some of the local chapters.

pros: The advocacy department is amazing! Great work-life balance and very rewarding work!

pros: Many staff members have been personally touched by Alzheimer's and passion for their work is evident.
cons: Current reorg is taking toll on many, especially in care and support. Senior mgmt states the Association is committed, yet blocks any initiatives, funding or new staff to support these activities.

pros: The mission is honest and pure, the company values diversity and inclusion, and the culture really does feel like working as a part of a team.
cons: It is a really big organization, so  sometimes the bureaucracy that comes along with that can be frustrating.

review_title: Like most of the staff who was not senior management, I looked at every opportunity for another job.

review_title: Supporting an important cause, but association could be run much more efficiently and effectively.
